title.narrative: Duboko extension: Regional solid waste management project in Serbia
Duboko utökning: Regionalt Avfallshanterings- projekt i Serbien

description.narrative:
Det regionala avfallsbolaget, PUC Duboko, startade byggandet av en regional avfallsdeponi under 2008 med stöd av EBRD, EU, Serbiens regering och Sida. Deponin togs i drift 2011 och projektet är nyligen avslutat. På grund av en illa vald plats för deponin, (brant område nära ett vattendrag),så är bolaget nu i akut behov av ytterligare stöd för att stabilisera deponin och också utöka den. Ett nytt jordskred skulle med stor sannolikhet sätta stopp för bolagets verksamhet för lång tid framåt och också orsaka betydande förorening av områdets vattendrag. Insatsen har därför bedömts vara ett projekt av akut karaktär.
Målet med projektet är att; stabilisera deponin, utöka deponiområdet samt ge expertstöd för att effektivisera bolagets verksamhet (hållbar drift där intäkter täcker kostnader) samt stärka ministeriets kapacitet att stödja kommunala miljöprojekt. Sida ger genom denna insats stöd till den delen av projektet som avser att stabilisera och utöka deponin. För detta ändamål ämnar Sida kanalisera 23 MSEK genom EBRD. En viktig anledning till ett fortsatt samarbete med EBRD är att EBRD snabbt kan göra ett tilläggskontrakt med befintlig entreprenör.
Genom befintligt svenskt stöd till miljöministeriet, "the Environmental Infrastructure Support Program" (EISP), har redan förberedande stöd till projektet förmedlats i form teknisk assistans och rådgivning (med tanke på det akuta läget).
Utökningen av deponin planeras ske genom att konstruera ytterligare ytor direkt nedanför och på den södra sidan av den befintliga deponin. Deponering av avfall nedanför dagens tipp bidrar också till att stabilisera deponin och möjliggör på så sätt att ytterligare öka kapaciteten genom att möjliggöra deponering på högre nivåerna.

The Public Utility Company of Duboko, owned by 9 municipalities in the region, started the construction of a regional landfill in 2008, financially supported by EBRD, EU the Serbian government and Sida. The project has been completed and the landfill is in operation since 2011. Due to the poor location of the landfill site, and risk for landslides, PUC Duboko urgently needs to stabilize and extend the landfill in order to continue its operations. A new major landslide is likely to put an end to PUC Duboko operations for some time to come. It would probably also cause serious pollution of the Turkish creek, which runs close to the landfill area.
The proposed new Duboko sustainability project aims to provide additional disposal capacity of minimum 2.5 years, increase the stability of the landfill to minimize the risk for new landslides and, through technical assistance, improve the operational performance of PUC Duboko and support the Ministry’s development of a realistic municipal solid waste investment pipeline.
The stabilization and extension of the landfill site would consist of disposal directly below and to the south of the current site. This would not only provide more space for landfilling but also stabilize the whole site, allowing for disposal on the higher etages 4 and 5, which is not possible today (due to the risk of land slide). In total it would allow a minimum of 2.5 years of additional disposal capacity and there is space on the south side to continue disposal for approximately 25 years (that will be done at a later stage, I e not supported by this project).
Through the Swedish supported Environmental Infrastructure Support Program (EISP), support has already started to strengthen the operational, managerial and financial aspects of PUC Duboko's services and have also supported the initial technical preparations for the new construction. The support from EISP will contine, with already decided funding, and will provide complimentary work to the actual construction work which will be managed by EBRD. Sida has channeled funds through EBRD for the earlier support to Duboko and consider this the most feasible option also for the extension considering the urgency and need for immediate action.
The overall objective is to improve the sustainability of the the Regional Waste Management Centre Duboko to the point where tipping fees and revenues cover operating costs.

description.narrative: To summarise the latest performance of the project a short summary is useful. Background (to a large extent based on EISP reports) The aim of the Swedish contribution is to 1) re-design the pipe and 2) provide a new space for landfilling in order to mitigate risks of landslides and pollution and secure the sustainability of the project. Importantly, the orignial landfill construction was financed through an EBRD loan without Swedish support which has been paid off in 2016. The original waste separation line was financed with an EU grant, and Swedish support was limited to grants to repair landslides. The project has a key regional role since it is covering nine municipalities and approximately 350.000 population, and a number of tourists visiting the region, why the Ministry of Environment, EBRD and Sweden has stayed committed to the project although, encouraging progress to be made. The stabilisation and extension design (for construction permit) was done through EISP1/IMG under Swedish grant funding. It was delivered and accepted in 2016 by Duboko PUC. When the works contractor was hired in 2017, they claimed that the proposed design for the pipe strengthening would not work. The reason for the original pipe design error goes back to input data provided by the Contractor to the Designer, but there were also missing components in the design. The Supervisor was tasked by the EBRD Procurement Department with identifying where the fault lay but was unable to do so as Duboko appeared to have no documents relating to the existing pipe construction. Moreover, the previous works were never formally taken over by Duboko as the Employer. Although Sweden was not involved at the stage of the orignial design of the pipe, Sweden has clearly underlined the need to follow-up on the responsiblities of the bad original construction and on the need have sufficient technical information on the construction in order to provide a sustainable re-design of the pipe. It was agreed by concered parties in the beginning of 2018 that the proposed design had to be updated to meet the actual needs. The Supervisor was tasked with preparing a ToR for the design update on behalf of the end user / Employer (Duboko PUC). Duboko PUC resisted the development of the ToR, would not provide the background information needed about the site, then would not agree on the type of design required under Serbian law (Design for Construction), then would not accept the Supervisor’s / EISP’s version. To try to break the deadlock, EISP 2 financed a ‘Component 1: Assessment Report’ by the original Designer to agree the scope of the required design update. That was consulted, presented, and agreed by all parties in early July 2018. EISP developed a simplified version of the ToR for the purposes of contracting, but Duboko PUC would still not not accept the version presented by EISP and supported by the Ministry of Environment. This was the status of the project at the time of the last conclusion of performance. Results, expected and unexpected Awaiting the lack of progress on approving the ToR for the the re-design, the amendement to the grant agreement between EBRD and Duboko expired in the summer 2018. This lead to a need for a broader assessment of how to move ahead with the project, where the Ministry of Environment supported by EBRD and Sweden agreeed that a pre-requisite to go ahead was a clear and also contractual committment including the Ministry in the execution of the project, as well as the importance of following up on responsiblities of badly constructed pipeline and the weak performance in supervision and by Duboko PUC. The Ministry is actively involved in other infrastructure projects, with important deliverables. The Swedish Embassy engaged in trying to facilitate developments of the project, consulting Sida Stockholm, and EBRD stepped up its engagement. During the fall 2018 the Ministry, EBRD and Sweden had a close dialogue on re-design of the project set up, and EBRD and the Ministry has followed up with concerned parties (ie Engineer, Employer, Contractor and the nine founding municpalities). During the spring 2019 the focus shifted to get formal committment by the Ministry of Environment and the concerned munipalities on a re- desgn of the project set up, including Ministry in the governance structure of the Dubuco PUC. Sweden (the Embassy) has underlined the need for clear roles and responsiblities and transparency in project implemenation is necessary to get sustainable results. EBRD has during the last year increased its level of committment, and has actively followed-up the responsibiliteis of the badly constructed pipeline and how to move ahead with the Supervision consultant (Engineer) and Duboko PUC. The re-design set up is now under discussion, including a new grant agreement between EBRD and Ministry/municipalities, an update of the contrubution agreement between EBRD-SE, a lendors monitor financed by Sweden, a review of the status of contractor and supervision and a revision of the financial plan. The Embassy has expressed that with the increased ownerhip and committment of the Ministry and municipalities the role of EISP would not be further needed. In July 2019 EBRD met with the Minister for Environment to discuss how the role of the Minsitry could be formalised in the project. The Minsitry has returned with the confirmation to actively engage, and EBRD is now following-up if a suitable organisational set up is possible, assuring active Ministry involvement. Whilst the results on the ground are still non-existant, another "lost year" of construction is likely and the formal re-design of the project is yet to be concluded. At the same time the intensified dialogue and the proposed re-design of the project set-up being discussed should be seen as important developments as to sustainably increasing the ownership by the Ministry of Environment and the engagment of the municipalities, which would be key for any further developments.
